Please give Shinsekai Yori a try, it's a show that demands all of your attention, you will be surprised by the twists, I enjoyed this much more then I expected!


The animation actually can be breath taking at times, but at other times the characters look like scribblings, it has a funny effect though and fits well in the story. There's no opening for this anime (I don' know if I have ever seen that before lol) but there are two different endings. The soundtracks we hear are mostly by an orchestra or a children's choir, that give you goosebumps like crazy! Again it fits perfectly to the story, no Japanese pop music to be expected here ;)


The characters are...awesome and thankfully realistic. The girls kick ass, the parents aren't preaching, the boys make out with each other and that's perfectly normal, the government sucks, like in real life, and the queerats have balls! I was so happy that this anime didn't turn out to be one of those, that have a good plot, but terribly stereotypical acting characters! Like I said before there are a lot of time skips so the characters grow and change after every few episodes, but that is what's so awesome about this show. This could have gone really bad, rushing through important steps of life, but Shinsekai yori doesn't miss the important steps, no, everything you see matters, even those small things you wouldn't even dream of to be the slightest relevant, are relevant for the story, big props to the writer of the novel 'Shinsekai Yori' (in the U.S. also knowns as 'From the New World') that this anime was adapted from, Yusuke Kishi. Great message that makes you think about our society, and all the things, we could do better. It's pretty depressing actually...humans are cruel animals, but we can change. Yeah, that's my conclusion.

I watched Shinsekai Yori long, long ago. The reason I never really reviewed it is from the fear of being too biased towards the show since I instantly graded it 10 and labeled it my all-time favorite anime. You must be asking: "But --- but, it's still graded 10 and still your all-time favorite anime! What's up with that?" - now that I've re-watched the show, knowing the ending and all of the twists basically, I was able to catch a few to several inconsistencies in story, world, art, characters etc. - but did it really take away anything from the show? Not really. 
ShinsekaiYori tells a story that spans over the fourteen years in total, with two time-shifts in its entirety. Both time-shifts occur after some meaningful events so to keep this review spoiler-less I'll try avoiding the talk about them. The story is told from the perspective of Saki, a young girl with friends and family like any other. It basically starts with their little group having a camping trip and learning something they should have not - as well for us to being exposed to acts of foreplay between two twelve year old kids. Oh well. In essence, if they had never learned what they did that day, they would have never really been caught up into story THAT much - we'd still have some conflicts which had affected the world, but the story this way is quite personal. 


Since the story in itself has numerous twists I cannot go into detail, so I'll try and go roundabout. In a sense it's a fantastical story but extremely realistic at the same time. It's put a thousand years into the future of today, with humans living seemingly peaceful lives full of love and care. The story consists of several twists and turns - some expected, others not as much - with some certain "hey, what about that? That's not the way you said it was!" moments. These moments, albeit rare, do somewhat take away from that episode - but not from the entire series. It is a story more turned towards mature than kid side, having several twists which are extremely thought-provoking all through to the end and beyond. It starts as extremely slow-paced establishment and basically nothing happens until episode 10 or so - only world building. For some, like me, who really appreciate world building this has come as a breath of fresh air. Before the story essentially kicks off, you're pretty much familiar with world - its origin and its present, which helps a lot when trying to accumulate thoughts as to why certain things are happening. Extremely well done and crafted story - that's all I've got to say.  


The first thing you'll most-likely notice is imaginative art. While it may not be spectacular and ever-evolving, it is certainly different. It's extremely well done and oftentimes it shifts as the mood of the scene changes - gradient hues take over, coloring the world green/purple or any other dimming color. It has it's bright moments of course, but most of the major events occur in dark spaces. Another thing I must praise this show for are the backgrounds - they are absolutely breathtaking. I'd take a bet that in each episode you can extract at least 4-5 beautiful, completely different wallpapers for your desktop. While animation may be lacking sometimes, some scenes are extremely well done (like Saki falling through the sky, or Saki and Satoru running through the tunnels etc.) and worth a praise. Characters are all unique when it comes to art department, each having its own distinguishing trait but also quite some symbolism in the very character department - Saki, throughout the entire series, remains as one character (out of main ones, to be precise) who is most-likely to be present in real life. For instance Maria has extremely long, red hair and blue eyes, Shun and Satoru have hard-to-make hairstyles as well as that kid no one really remembers. In that sense it helps us to relate to Saki from whose perspective this story is told. 

On the other side of production team we have sound. I've got to say - if the soundtrack of "The Fountain" is my all-time favorite movie OST, this Shinsekai Yori wins in anime department. "Kage no Denshouka Dainibu" to list one of many is simply shiver-worth soundtrack which befits each scene it's placed into. It's quite grappling and, even when listened outside the context of series, is extremely beautiful - to an extent where I'd put it among my favorite themes ever (probably just after "Death is the Road to Awe" from Clint Mansel). Voice actors (and actresses) put up an virtuous effort in delivering their characters. I especially must give credit to Namikawa Daisuke, a man who gave a voice to the character of Squealer - probably the most amazing performance among amazing performances. So yeah ... production ... much wow. 


Now we come to the character department. It's really hard to label these characters - not because they're not developed or anything but because they're just simply ... humans. All of them (oops). They all deal with certain issues in their own ways, each tackling a certain problem the best way they see fit. That's what makes each of them unique and fun to observe and even relate to. For instance, Saki has qualms about dealing with at-the-moment perilous situation, but she has easier way of moving on. Satoru on the other hand handles the present situation which requires quick answer easily but has a harder time of moving on. And so on and so forth. All these things make each character you see in the series developed and ... relate-able. Regardless of whether you like them or not, when their story comes to fruit, you can feel for them all the same. That's one of the greatest strengths of Shinsekai Yori - characters are not badass stereotypes who go round spouting badass one-liners. They're all humans - they can act though, but that's all there is to it - an act. 


This has been my longest review since ... well, ever. The reason being is that I tried to deliver Shinsekai Yori to those who hadn't watched it the best way possible without spoiling anything - which is actually extremely difficult. All the juice of Shinsekai Yori lies in the spoilers. But oh well. I managed to slip one or two in there. I'm a monster. 


I quickly understood that Shinsekai Yori won't be for everyone. Aside from two frame yaoi and yuri moments we have in the 8th episode (man did a lot of people drop the show because of it. Why? Beats me.), Shinsekai Yori starts extremely slowly. And the pace never really goes over-the-top-full-of-action. It always takes its time to establish things and characters, without simply rushing head-on to the conclusion (well, aside from first 4 minutes of last episode ... BADASS MOMENT!) . At times it has weird art-style and the story is simply sometimes hard to follow. It's quite thought-provoking and I can see why some people would simply get bored of it. All I'm asking of you is to give it a chance. Watch an episode per day if you find it boring and if you keep tackling the issues the show is, I promise you you'll have a great time.


Now, do I recommend Shinsekai Yori? Well ... isn't that kind of obvious? I do. I may still seem biased (probably because I am?) but that does not take away anything from the show - if anything, it should help you decide whether to pick it up or not. Pick it up. It actually just might surprise you.

We often see anime adapted from manga, but we rarely see an anime adapted from a young adult novel. This much lauded anime is adapted from a Japanese young adult novel, that itself is basically an adaptation/remake of 2 classic dystopian novels from the early 20th century. Shinsekai Yori translates as "From the New World", which is appropriate since it borrows heavily from both the novel " Brave New World" by Aldous Huxley and especially from a lesser known 1924 novel called "We" by Yevgeny Zamyatin. Shinsekai also seems to take some inspiration from Harry Potter with one of the major conflicts being between wizardsupremacists and non-magic users, whom I will simply call "muggles" for the rest of this review.


WARNING! THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS! 


Story: 7/10


In the year 2011, ex-Soviet mad scientists in Azerbaijan created a mutagen turning humans into magic users. The mutagen spread until 0.5 percent of the population were wizards. The wizards then wiped out 99% of the muggles in a few years and formed brutal dictatorships with the most powerful wizards serving as dictators. The muggles were forced to be slaves of course. For the first 600 years there were 19 Wizard dictatorships with muggle slaves that lived under an uneasy truce. There were also a few groups of muggle hunter gatherers, and small groups of wizard scientists, who built the last biotic computers since nearly all books had been destroyed. Japan alone contained 4 of the Wizard empires because Japanese wizards were rather quarrelsome. A problem arose when the Cherry Blossum Empire’s last ruler was a complete madman who killed half its population. In order to create order and peace, Japanese Wizard scientists through brain washing and genetic engineering were able to make it so killing another human resulted in your own death. However, this meant wizards couldn’t kill muggles either. To correct this and put down the muggles once and for all, the surviving muggles were rounded up and mutated into mole-men with inferior intelligence and a different enough genetic code that wizards could still kill them. The mole-men then became the new slaves of the more peaceful wizard societies. However, some mole-men continued to foster dreams of rebellion. Any humans born to Wizard families that don’t have magic powers (Squibs) are sacrificed in the tradition of ancient Sparta, only with giant cat monsters instead of leaving the infants out to die. Those who cheat at mandatory wizard school are also killed by the Government’s cat monsters. In addition to heavy brainwashing, the Wizard police state in which our characters live is able to pacify the population by promoting LOTS of casual sex both heterosexual and homosexual. 


The mechanism that kills Wizards who commit murder, works by hypnosis shutting down the murderer’s liver once the murderer is aware they killed someone (hypnosis can’t actually do that BTW) and this causes high potassium levels (liver failure actually causes LOW potassium levels) and the high K levels cause a heart attack. However, there are 2 types of mutants that can still kill people. The first are “fiends” who can slaughter people without suffering death feedback. The second are “Karma Demons” who can’t control their powers and kill people unintentionally and thusly avoid triggering the hypnosis. The reason the government kills anyone not in full control of their magic, or who cheats, or who doesn't develop magic early enough, is presumably to prevent “fiends” and Karma Demons” from appearing. In the current year of 3,000 AD, there is a global population of 70 million wizards and an unknown number of Mole-men, but we know not nearly as many as wizards. Wizard communities are surrounded by powerful barriers that citizens believe were built to keep them safe, but were actually built to keep them in, and stop their magic from warping the environment any more than it already has.


Pretty impressive background world huh? A true masterpiece! Here is why I was less impressed than most of my fellow MAL users. I read obscure classic novels that aren't on the summer reading list...because I'm a nerd. Let's look at the similarities with "We". 

1. dystopian Police State taking place exactly 1,000 years in the future. 2. Government rules though brain washing, genetic engineering, and brutal force used by secret police at the behest of a shady government council. 3. LOTS of casual sex both heterosexual and homosexual is encouraged to keep citizens passive. 4. A wall is built around the nation that people think is protecting them, but is actually keeping them in. 5. Anyone who dissents and is not executed has their memories wiped. 6. Outside the wall are hairy "beast men" that are the mutant descendants of those not conquered by the Police State. 7. The hairy beast men lead a revolt against the government and do major damage to it. 8. The novel ends open ended with some optimism towards a better future. 


The line between homage and complete ripoff is thin. However, if a great story is forgotten and young readers refuse to give it a chance, is it a sin to make a reboot that better captures the hearts of young readers? I actually don't think so. That is most of the reason I rated Shinsekai as highly as I did. Now that background is out of the way, we will proceed to look at the actual plot itself.


We follow a group of 5 young magic users who must uncover the brutal secrets of their society and unearth the brutal history that led them to this point. At the same time they must go to Wizard school and perfect their magic...or else. The major conflict occurs when a highly charismatic yet extremely treacherous member of the mole-men attempts to raise an army to wipe out the wizards and become the dominant species on Earth. His name is "Squeaker", but I will refer to him as Mole-neto. We the audience learn more about the society in each episode, but unfortunately our heroes keep getting their memories erased by the wizard government, so we have to hear things repeated again and again! However, the wizard government doesn't want to kill our leading lady Saki, because she has amazing leadership skills and has been handpicked to be the next ruler of the most powerful organization of the Wizard Police State called the Ethics Committee, who are basically like the Wizard KGB. Eventually Mole-neto is defeated and our MC ends the show wishing to gradually make her society suck less!


Characters: 6/10


We have 5 main characters, but unfortunately most of them aren't very interesting or well developed. The character that gets the VAST majority of the character building and development is Saki Watanabe, our MC girl. Saki is a brilliant strategist, intelligent, kindhearted, yet logical and highly pragmatic. She is sort of like if you combined Inspector Akane from Psychopass with Legolas from LOTR. Her only flaw is that she doesn't have any god damn flaws! William Faulkner wrote that only flawed characters in deep conflict with themselves are worth reading about. It is true that when we think of the greatest characters of all time we're thinking: Hamlet, Raskolnikov, Pierre Bezukhov, not fucking Full Paragon Commander Shepard! I was even beginning to read her subtitles in Shepard's voice by the end! The anime gives at least a little effort trying to generate sympathy for Mole-neto, but he quickly undermines that by being a complete asshole with no redeeming qualities. He isn't generous to his own people, he doesn't have a code of honor, he doesn't have ANY of the anti-hero traits that made other villains like his namesake Magneto interesting. He's a fucking asshole! My favorite character BY FAR is Kiroumaru the Samurai Mole! He's a mole-man, who is also a samurai! That's fucking awesome! He also is honorable to a fault, and has disdain for humans, yet knows that the mole-men must co-exist with the wizards if they are to survive. He doesn't get NEARLY enough screen time!


Music: 5/10


The only really good music in this anime is Dvorak's "New World Symphony" (ya get it?)" which it plays the same short segment of...over....and over...and over. The best use was in the opening scene depicting the outbreak of the Wizard/Muggle war. A wizard kid with an ascot like Fred in Scooby Doo is splattering muggles to the calming sounds of Dvorak, creating unintentional hilarity! I'm not sure if it is how unfitting the music is, or the fact that you just CAN'T look threatening wearing an ascot!


Art: 8/10


The art is pretty damn good. It isn't Mushishi good or anything, but it is well above average.



Bonus Section: Plot Holes! Oh dear God the plot holes!


The anime spends a LOT of time trying to convince the viewer to have some sympathy for the utilitarian principals of the dystopian government, but much of their killing is actually pointless. They have Wizards that can seal off the power of any wizard and the seal can only be broken if someone else recites that wizard's personal incantation. The Wizard government are MASTERS of erasing memories as we learn over and over. Why not seal the problem child's powers, then erase problem child's special incantation from the minds of any close relatives or friends that happen to know it? Nope! Cat monsters! The novel may actually explain why this wouldn't work, but the anime leaves us with the impression that the Wizard government honestly never thought of it and are just a bunch of complete idiots! Our heroes get their powers sealed, but the government allows them to recite each other's mantras and restore each other's powers, even though this is supposed to be highly illegal. Hell, it even results in a character becoming a Karma Demon and destroying an entire city! Yet the government couldn't give less of a fuck! They just MIB everyone's memory for the upteenth time! You would think with all the genetic engineering and brainwashing they would have created an instant death trigger for someone who without authority reactivates a wizard's power that has been sealed by the police! Nope! They just have insta-death triggers for nearly every other illegal activity. Here is another HUGE problem with the plot. The Wizards won their war with the Muggles WAY too easily. It is clearly stated that the first wizards during the war didn't have training from wizard schools and magic had evolved to be FAR more powerful by the year 3,000. This is a problem because Satoru is an A class wizard from the year 3,000 AD, who has been training his entire life, yet gets tired fighting hoards of mole-men using primitive bows and arrows! Yet the vastly weaker and untrained wizards of the past shit stomped muggle armies with tanks, machine guns, and jet fighters and were able to each rack up a 200-1 kill ratio. It also turns out for some poorly explained reason that magic is much more effective as an offensive than defensive weapon. Even an S class wizard/Ninja gets killed easily by fucking Mole-men when he has to go on defense. You can't win outnumbered 200 to 1 with no defense! The muggles would have taken that war with sheer attrition. It isn't like the wizards had H-bomb level attacks! Even the most powerful wizards from 3,000 AD couldn't do that!



Overall: 7/10


Shinsekai Yori wasn't the perfect series that so many MAL critics seem to think it is. However, it was a pretty solid series and a decent adaptation of old dystopian novels that this generation might actually enjoy...unlike Brave New World which literally every student HATES having to read in school. Were the characters great? Not really. Did the series have a lot of plot holes? Yes it did. However, Shinsekai also made young viewers have to think about government abuse of power, utilitarianism and security vs. humanism and freedom, the dangers of nationalism and discrimination, and how far one should go to protect your own freedom against tyranny. Is Shinsekai as good as "We" ? FUCK no it isn't! However, if you  have a little brat that won't eat his healthy vegetables and only wants to eat ice cream and Hershey's bars, wouldn't you settle for seeing him eat yogurt with a bit of fruit? It isn't broccoli, but it is a HUGE improvement over Hershey's and ice cream. For being at least a decent, modern adaptation of something legitimately great, Shinsekai does deserve some praise!

Humans always dreamed. We dream all the time. We have dreams we all want to fulfill. Thanks to our imagination, those dreams can be endless. Everybody has imagination and anybody can have any kind of thoughts at any time. But what can happen if what we imagine, even what we dream (awake or sleep), at least just a piece of it, can become real? Great? Just remember than some people have nightmares, some people are evil, and some others are completely rotten.
Shinsekai Yori really gives credits to its title, a fantasy new world in Japan 1000, years ahead in the future, where people have Cantus:A complex kind of telekinesis, like an extension of the body for those who use it. But we will see that Cantus is much more than that.


Shinsekai Yori will show us a beatiful but complex world, filled with weird but interesting creatures, societies that hide lots and lots of secrets, and the story of Saki and her group of friends and how they are dragged to figure out what's is behind all the darkness and mysteries. An outstanding tale where the years go and go, and we will get to see how much each character change and get stronger or weaker. We will see how much Saki grows up and start to face her fears.


This anime doesn't care of genres or beliefs: with a precious style of animation, a fluid motion, watching all the exciting plot twist this anime has to offer, and a gem of soundtrack, Shinsekai Yori can break any expectation. You will see beatiful settings; both endings will let you feel all the story going throught your thoughts and your body and the final episodes will let you with a sensation of "Damn!".


Because nothing is perfect, it has some flaws: A slow begining where you can feel a bit bored, and some few episodes just in the middle of the story where you can feel that again; but the story will always snowball out of control, hit you in the face, and you will feel it hard. Each arc is really interesting and will end with a surprise.


My conclusion: Shinsekai Yori is a master piece of anime. It is the anime that nobody knows about but everybody should watch. I really want more people to watch it and appreciate it as much as I do.

Where to begin... First of all, I saw this from someone else's recommendation and I got to say: anyone who did not watch this anime definitely should. This anime is one of the few that affected me in real life (another one is Psycho-pass). I chose Shinsekai yori as my first anime review because that is simply how good this anime is. It isn't mainstream and action packed with blazing fights. This anime is on a whole different level than most of the other ones I watched and its unorthodox elements captivated and drew me in the anime even more. It makes you do alot of thinking and can change what your beliefs are if it is that influential. Once you have seen it, you can't brush it off as another anime that you've watched. It will stick with you and you will ponder about it for a long time. (Some spoilers, but not too much)


The beginning of the anime started out as creepy and dark, but it did well to build up the suspense and the story later on. It might be a little confusing to understand the plot and the setting of the story but after a few episodes you understand when the story is taking place, how the people get there, and what they are talking about. The story is filled with elements of an utopia, dystopia, murder, adventure, ESP, horror, romance, and others. However, the things that struck me most were the horror parts of the story. The thriller suspense made me shiver and cold sweats were beading down my face. It also made me want to skip some parts of the episodes. 


The story has some time slips with the focus on the protagonist, Saki, and with her, we can see the growth of a child and how she grew up from this world that is beginning to seem twisted in her mind. We can see the influence of the world it has on Saki and her group of friends, as they all begin to change and develop into significant characters. Saki, above all, is the greatest protagonist as you see her growth into an adult and mature mindset. You would assume that this is a world with only humans but you later realize that there is another sentient foreign species that revere the humans as gods. It is also quite interesting that this story introduces the policies and treatment of foreign species, and we can easily reflect that to real life events. As a result, this anime isn't simply superficial but the author of the novel tried to incorporate aspects of the real world to the anime.


All in all, the art was great, the story fantastic, the music adding to the suspense and thriller, the characters were outstanding (even the nonhumans), and I really, really enjoyed it. 10/10.

Hope you had fun reading my first review and ultimately see this amazing anime. Shinsekai yori FTW.

Tens, tens all across the boards, I was quite excited to see this anime especially with its popularity on MAL and its popularity in the reviews, aside from this review that I am currently writing, all of them consisted of a positive review. I was impressed, not even one person gave Shinsekai Yori a low score...I guess that I am going to have to be that person. 
Shinsekai Yori is an anime adapted from its novel counterpart that released in 2012, after seeing its positive praise I decided to pick it up, so here are my thoughts on the anime. 
Story 
If you're reading thisand you've also read the synopsis here my suggestion is to read this or on some wiki because the synopsis IS NO WHERE NEAR THE ACTUAL PLOT, I am serious. From reading it you'd assume it's probably some mystery  or something at least I did but nope the anime is doesn't revolve around that 'rumour' that is mentioned. 

Shinsekai Yori is set 1000 years into the future where humans have developed psychic abilities known as cantus. Due to this nature society has evolved and would seem perfect at least so it seems but of course there is more than meets the eye.  The anime then progresses over the lives of our characters and explore many themes that surround it. Its execution is more arc based as the story progresses in small plot elements that will later progress throughout the show. While I don't think is not a bad idea the general execution is well tiresome. Shinsekai Yori is a heavy exposition anime it requires a lot of attention to every detail so it may not exactly be your cup tea if you're not into heavy talking and while you're reading this thinking that I am incompetent to fully engage, I really did try with this anime. I wanted to love it but it was incredibly difficult. One of the problems was essentially the plot points in the show, a lot of them and I mean a lot are only brought up due to convenience when instead these plot points should've been brought up often. Another reason why I couldn't fully enjoy the story is because it develops on arcs where I just wasn't fully interested mainly because some arcs tend to fall astray from the main synopsis of the show or into characters which I never fully cared for. While the anime does explore themes it's only really the tip of the iceberg for example the ever so popular topic of same-sex relationships is explored and what I mean is essentially that people are just gay. The relationships or the themes is not deepening or explored fully it just happens, not that it's entirely a problem but with people praising it's use of theme-ing I couldn't really see it because what Shinsekai Yori is showing me makes it no different from any other relationship.  Also more personally but the plot twists to me in this show were incredibly predictable. 


Characters 

In terms of characters not many of them are interesting to begin with. The story revolves around a group of characters with Saki Watanabe being the main character, one of the major problems I had with her is essentially how much praise she got...for being normal. Everyone and I mean everyone in the show comments on how much potential she has or how amazing she is but all she does is just stands there, there are times where she is somewhat useful but she doesn't do many things interesting. The rest of the characters aren't exactly gold either, most of them don't hold much interest or exactly deepen the plot. There's very little care for characters in the show not until the later parts of the show but it's only briefly, it's quite the shame because with Shinsekai Yori deepening towards its society you could do some good character building but unfortunately the characters are just there, you could replace the characters with anyone and it wouldn't impact the show in the slightest. 


Presentation

The art style is pretty good except for one design of characters that I don't particularly like, that being the queerats. They can die but the rest of the animation and art is pretty good to look at, I didn't mind it. The soundtrack of the anime is pretty good, I quite liked it one of the few anime osts that I have indeed noticed and thought it was pretty good and despite this anime not having an opening the ending theme for it is pretty awesome. 


Conclusion 

Personally Shinsekai Yori is an overrated anime to me. Its plot is all over the place and is pretentious by attempting to explore many themes present in our society today but it's not a good attempt to me especially with its bland characters. Maybe there's just something wrong with me because a lot of people love this anime but personally I just couldn't enjoy it which leaves me with my final rating of this anime being 6.

Shinsekai Yori (From the New World in English) was recommended to me with the words "Psychic pansexuals in a dystopian future with rat people and good music and you will cry," which ended up describing the series far better than I thought it would. This anime was definitely one that pulled me in from the get-go, and kept me interested the whole way through.
Story: 9/10
Though this show starts off with a vague beginning, things don't take long to pick up and get good. This story centers around five characters and spans many years, so we get to see the characters grow from mere children toindependent adults.

Shinsekai Yori features an interesting tale of people who have psychic powers as well as the strange rat people that worship them as gods. Though this show takes place in Japan, the worldbuilding is astounding. This takes place far in the future, yet we get to see exactly how we ended up in this isolated country where utopian/dystopian governments reign. We also get to see the organization of the simpler-minded monster rats (I watched the dub, so I know them as monster rats, but in the Japanese they're called queerats). Though they lead a simple life, the inner workings of their government system impressed me. They're not quite as dumb as the characters think they are.

This show heads along at a fair pace: not too fast and not too slow. It also feels as if it's holding its breath for something larger to happen later on (and happen it does, but I'll avoid talking about it because of spoilers).

One of the things this show really excelled in was the foreshadowing. Early on, it gives you all the keys you need to unlock the plot twists coming later, yet you never notice it until it happens. This show takes on the nature of a self-fulfilling prophecy in a way. It's definitely worth a rewatch (though I haven't rewatched it myself yet), just to see exactly how well the show foretold its own ending.

Another really amazing thing about the show was the suspense factor. This show creates a really interesting atmosphere that draws you into the story and characters, to the point where you almost feel like you're there with them. One especially notable suspense part was when two characters are hiding from something unknown. At this point, all music stops and it goes completely silent, where all the characters can do is simply hold their breath. I found myself holding my breath too, and staring wide-eyed at the screen until the moment passed.

At the end, the show finally releases the suspense it's been holding you in since the beginning and throws out a plot twist that makes the rest of the story pieces suddenly click into place. Once it's revealed, you wonder how you didn't think of this before, since as I said, it was foreshadowed right from the start.

There were some negative aspects of the story, though. It's not perfect by any means, but it's still really darn good. 

One of the main things that bothered me was sometimes the show would create suspense for things but not really capitalize on them, or resolve them in a completely different way than what they seemed to be doing.

For example, there was the dystopian government, which I guess didn't really turn out to be dystopian at all. There was talk of punishment, but that didn't really ever happen in a definitive way. There was also one part which made me say "Oh shit" out loud, but didn't end up resulting in anything.

In addition to that, the show has an infodump at one point that didn't result in what they hinted it would, but it was a creatively done infodump, so I'll let it slide.

I felt like the problems were caused by the show getting too involved in other things to properly resolve some confusion in the beginning, but the positives of the story overwhelmingly outshine the negatives.


Shinsekai Yori definitely has a subtle note about the darker side of humanity, and is a fairly simple, linear tale about five kids learning the truth of their world. And one by one, they start to disappear.


Art: 7/10

This show was airing at around the same time as Sword Art Online, another A-1 production, so it missed out on the spotlight and the budget for the most part. The characters lack shading and the eyes are mostly one color, so it may take some time to get used to the flat-color look. In terms of animation, it's above average but not anything spectacular. However, it gets a 7 rather than a 6 because some of the scenery shots were simply gorgeous. A couple that stood out to me were a sky full of stars in one of the early episodes and a sunset backdrop in the second ED, but there were a lot of good background pictures. Sometimes the backgrounds looked a little sloppy and too obviously hastily painted in, but for the most part they were very colorful and detailed.

I also liked the look of the monster rats, who were grotesque creatures with bulging eyes and clawed hands. Even though they weren't pretty to look at, I have to give the show props for creating these ugly creatures because they do look a lot like mutated naked mole rats, the creatures they're based off of.


Sound: 8/10

An interesting thing about Shinsekai Yori is that it doesn't have an opening. The show simply jumps right into the episode and places the opening credits alongside the action. It may be weird to get used to, but I think it suits this anime since I can't really imagine it with a peppy J-rock number as per the norm.

This show does have ending songs though, both of which were good but not legendary.

The OST of this show was good. It wasn't anything super amazing or unique, but in terms of using it effectively, the show rose above and beyond. They also knew when less is more, stopping the music at key parts to let the scene carry itself. 

This OST doesn't demand to be noticed. It's there and compliments the scene from behind, adding to the mood and effect without overshadowing the other aspects.


As I mentioned earlier, I watched the dub of this show. This show was dubbed by ADV, and I have a strong dislike for ADV dubs in general, since they range from mediocre to just plain bad (other ADV dubs include Angel Beats, No. 6, and Penguindrum). For this show, I thought the voice acting in general was good and improved later, but I was not a fan of some of the casting choices (though I don't think ADV has a huge range of voice actors to pick anyway, which is why they end up reusing so many).

I think the standout dub voice for me is Squealer, the ambiguous monster rat that keeps appearing throughout the story. He has a nasal, unpleasant-sounding voice that I think perfectly suits the character. It may not be the nicest on the ears, but it's definitely a realistic voice (in my opinion) for this type of creature.

I haven't seen any of the original Japanese of this show, but I'm sure it's better than the dub. I'd recommend watching this show subbed, unless you really, really want to watch it dubbed.


Characters: 8/10

The story revolves around five kids who grow into adults. These five kids all have their own personalities and are interesting in their own ways, but we don't really get to see much of what happened to them before the show started. I would have liked to see a little more of their childhood, since it seems like they've known each other for a while.

There's also the pansexuals aspect, which I didn't have a problem with, though some people may be turned off by it (There's a reason for that, I promise. It doesn't turn into a yaoi/yuri anime and it's not shown in a fetishized way). In the beginning, there's some hinted (boy/girl) relationships between characters, but nothing for certain. Then there's a timeskip, and we suddenly see a lot of boy/boy and girl/girl. That was a rather sudden change for me, but as I said it has a specific reason.

The reason the characters category is getting an 8 out of 10 rather than a 9 is because there wasn't much character development, aside from the main character Saki. She grew and changed a lot during the show, while her four friends were rather sidelined until important things happened to them. Overall though, the characters were very well done and I really enjoyed seeing the growth Saki and her friends underwent.


Enjoyment: 10/10

My enjoyment score is partially based on how quickly I watch a show, and I think I broke some kind of record with this one. The first day I watched the first 14 episodes, and watched the remaining 11 the day after. The show was so addictive that I wanted to know more and more, and before I knew it I was halfway through.

Besides how quickly I watched it, I thoroughly enjoyed the simple, linear, yet unique story, the effective background music, and the genius use of foreshadowing. This was definitely one that captured my interest the whole way through and did not get boring at all.


Overall: 9/10

As I said, some things that the show fell flat on, but by and large an interesting and unique tale about where humanity would go if given a certain power. I definitely recommend watching/rewatching this show, since I loved it, and I think most people will too.


I've said enough now. It's time for you to watch an anime about psychic pansexuals in a dystopian future with rat people and good music and crying.

let's see. to be completely honest, i was very disappointed in this. although in this animes defense i went into watching it expecting to see something that this anime is not.
a friend recommended this anime to me a while back, and the only thing he told me about it was "its about telekinetics" witch i absolutely love. i adore telekinesis in just about anything, especially anime. now, that is probably why i didn't enjoy this anime as much as other people. i went into it expecting to see what i wanted to see instead of watching the anime for what it is. what made mewatch the series in the first place was the first episode. as a mater of fact. the first few minutes of the first episode entranced me. it was perfect to say the least. the visuals, the sound, everything about those first few minutes caught my attention, sadly though, that same intro ruined this anime. that intro set my expectations pretty high, making the rest of Shinsekai yori a huge disappointment.


Story: 5/10

in many review of this anime people usually put 10/10 or 9/10 etc... but i just don't see it. like i was talking about the intro set a standard the rest of the anime failed to reach. in the first episode of shinsekai yori, it stars off with very mellow dramatic music and a boy. in the intro this boy is going around the neighborhood absolutely wrecking the place using his TK (telekinesis) killing people left and right, kicking the army's ass without a care in the world. so i assume the rest of this anime will be about TK users VS the world. WRONG! this anime is about TK users VS giant mutant cats and giant mutated naked mole rats. thats right, the main antagonistic force throughout the entirety of this anime, are a bunch of over sized talking giant naked mole rats. i found this, to say the least, horribly disappointing to the point where it was almost laughable. now, this aside, the over all story in itself is pretty "meh" it is hard to descripe without giving away spoilers. so for now the only way i could possibly describe the story of this anime is "meh"  


art: 9/10 

the art style used in this anime is pretty interesting. they use a mix of very subtle gradients and an interesting blend of color. although there is one odd episode where the art changes to a more "cashern sins" style and then goes back to normal in the next episode.


sound: 9/10 

the soundtrack used in this anime caught me off guard. in a good way. although there is no one track i feel like listening to outside of the anime itself. the music used flowed flawlessly with what was going on in the anime and enveloped you into the universe itself.


character: 8/10

characters in this anime are all very unique in their own way. each character has a defining personality, using a similar structure as any other anime but with enough originality that they become their own. there is a slight lack in character development and on occasion some characters will just vanish (pun :D)


enjoyment: 5/10

like i have said. the first episode set a standard the rest of this anime never met. i watched each episode hoping that maybe one of them will have the same feel as the intro did. sadly i finished the anime without once seeing the episode i had been weighting for. i was left disappointed, on top of that the paramount ending made me more upset with this series. 


overall: 5/10

although every other aspect of this anime was brilliant, i felt the plot fell short after the first 2 minutes of the first episode and left me horribly disappointed. i would only recommend this to people who enjoy watching people who have TK waste it away snow boarding, boating and fighting giant naked mole rats.

Shinsekai Yori squanders its promising premise with an abundance of tiresome exposition, cardboard characters, and a lethargic story line.
From the New World is a show that should be something so much more as the foundations of its premise should lead to a captivating and interesting story.  However, towards the middle of the first arc the issues with this anime became very apparent.
First of all, most of the story follows Saki and her friends as their quest for curiosity leads to them discovering the intentionally hidden mysteries of their world.  However, the show never devotes any time to learn much about Saki or mostof her group.  We don’t know anything about Saki’s interests, passions, or even what drives her to take an interest in the world around her.  Most of the time she feels very one dimensional and standard in nature.  This is also problematic because her stubborn and ungracious personality frequently turns a blind eye to the consequences of her actions.  Some of the time these ramifications even lead to her losing her friends and coping with life threatening situations, but when dealing with these repercussions she seems weirdly spoiled or as if she never expected to have to cope with any consequences at all.  The side cast is also very weak and standard in nature.  We know nothing about their families, interests, hobbies, or why they continue to follow Saki into danger.  There is almost no time devoted to their development as for most of the show the character’s personalities never change or grow.  At times they seem to clash with each other so often it left me pondering why they are even friends to begin with.  Most of the times when dealing with the fallout of following Saki they seem awkwardly nonchalant.  Satoru blindly follows Saki even though they fall out with each other multiple times throughout the show.  Maria is simply Saki’s friend and nothing more.  Mamoru is a one note character who's only trait is shyness, and most of the villagers and other members of the cast are granted so little screen time it is hard to be emotionally invested when darkness falls upon them.  With a show that features multiple arcs in which the characters are shown to progress in age from being kids to adults we never experience any situations that really change any of their personalities or allow us to identify with them on any level.


From the New World’s predictable and sluggish story line also leaves a lot to be desired.  The opening episode begins with a synopsis showing us the world in our present time and the humans that develop psychokinesis.  We also get information on why Saki’s world is the way it is and why kids are removed from society for extremely obvious reasons.  Then the show progresses as if we do not have that knowledge and focuses on Saki and her group discovering these reasons for the first 17 or so episodes of the show.  Ummm….. why?  Why do we need to follow Saki’s group and her friends discovering plot elements that we were so obviously shown in the first episode or beginning of the show?  Why is the show attempting to build suspense for answers we were already giving?  I’m not exactly sure myself and for the first two arcs of the show the lethargic pacing along with Saki’s oblivious reactions to the extremely obvious intentions of the Queerat character Squeeler was downright painful to sit through and comparable to having the most boring class in school during the final session of the day.


The largest and most glaring problem with this show is not only the worst aspect of the show but a problem that overflows into many of the show’s other issues already stated.  I am of course talking about the extreme overabundance of exposition that plagues the show and why sitting through this anime was a bad experience.  When watching a fantasy or mystery anime set in a different world that is not meant to be our own the main aspects that draw the audience into the story should be engaging or interesting events that SHOW the similarities and differences between our world and the fantasy world allowing the audience to become emotionally invested in the setting.  Many other shows do this by showing off the beauty/horrors of the world through the soundtrack and cinematography.  Others do so by alluding to the consequences of what could come if our characters fail to conquer the world.  Some shows simply take a breather to show how characters live and interact with each other and the world on a daily basis in the fantasy realm.  Unfortunately, Shinsekai yori never does this, and to make matters worse what shows up more often is the lowest common denominator of boring conversations between the characters describing how the rules of the world work assuming we are already invested.  Most episodes are nothing but explaining….. and explaining…… and more explaining.  The anime abandons all characterization as you rarely hear any natural human like conversations between anyone.  To make matters worse the anime is constantly throwing new terms at you as if it expects you to sit there and follow every bit of dialogue that consumes the majority of every episode.  This is made even worse when complemented by the fact that some of the dialogue is even focused on the political processes of how the world works as if CNN and Fox News weren’t bad enough.  All of the constant dialogue and explaining never stopped in any part of the show resulting in a hollow and empty experience.


This all being said I do recognize that this show is heavily praised by many people in the great anime community, so I will gladly touch on the redeeming factors.  As I mentioned above, the setting of a futuristic world as a result of an apocalypse happening in our lifetimes is pretty cool even if it is underutilized.  Also, even if it is uncommon, the show succeeds in making you feel uncomfortable or uneasy at times through its graphic visuals.  The strange scenes focusing on the sexual tension that plagues Saki’s group throughout the show also added to this uneasiness.  Lastly, even if it was simply explained rather than shown, the twist ending was pretty interesting and fit in well with the show’s overall themes.  


Unfortunately, these factors come nowhere close to making up for the overall headaches that plague this series.  Shinsekai Yori should be avoided at all costs.

Shin Sekai Yori (SSY) is an incredibly ambitious anime that fails to deliver. The initial premise for the series involves a society desperate to control its citizens due to the fear that any one of them could become a mass murderer due to misusing their cantus (magical powers) or simply losing control. In a similar manner, the creators of SSY managed to lose control of their own narrative.
It only takes four episodes before the show veers off course from its original premise. The first two episodes introduce the village and the cantus school where kids disappear frequently. This gets forgotten for episode 3 where anexposition dump tells us the dark history of the world, and that nothing has changed over the past few centuries; humans still murder anyone they are suspicious of. All of this information is forgotten the very next episode as Satoru and Saki begin mass murdering Queerats. Finally, when the kids return to the village where there's a possibility for them to act on the information that they just learned, there's a time skip and they've been brainwashed to forget everything. 


The show continues like this until the finale. Every development doesn't change how the characters behave because it's forgotten the next episode. Saki is completely incompetent with everything she does all the way through, even though the show tries to tell us how intelligent and capable she is. The other characters are just as incompetent with almost no personality. What this leaves us with is a show with bland characters making terrible decisions. The emotional parts of the story fall flat, and the climax of the story is completely ridiculous due to how easily it could have been avoided if any of the characters had any intelligence. The ending itself was insulting, trying to get us to empathise with a mass murderer who brainwashes his own people. 


The elements were there to make this one of my favourites. The soundtrack was great, and the haunting atmosphere and sense of mystery were enough to keep me hooked. However, once the show was over, I was disappointed. The series introduces many concepts that could be important to our future and are worth discussing, but the show never goes into any depth and usually uses these ideas as a means for plot conveniences (especially death feedback). Unlike other anime that explore similar concepts, there are no lessons to learn from SSY. The biggest praise I can give to SSY is how well it manages to masquerade itself as an intellectual anime.


I would not recommend anyone watch SSY.

"Maria was born two weeks after me.  She was also premature, and her condition after birth was even worse than mine. I think if Maria had never been born unto this world, then untold numbers could have been spared." - Saki, Shinsekai Yori
The word "Masterpiece" is a loan-translation of the dutch word meesterstuk, meaning the work by which a craftsman attains the rank of legend in the eyes of history. It's not a word a true critic such as myself would toss around lightly. (and I will probably receive a lot of down-votes for the bold statement I am about to make) In fact,of the nearly one hundred series I've seen over the years, there are only 3 animes I would consider true masterpieces. In an effort to abstain from angering the masses, I'll keep that bit of unnecessary information to myself. However, Shinsekai Yori ("From the New World") is undeniably, unforgettably, and unapologetically a true masterpiece of its time, the most recent of my memory. That's right. This is the diamond in the rough you've all been looking for. Don't let its severely underappreciated rank on myanimelist deceive you, Shinsekai Yori is undoubtedly one of the three greatest animes ever made. This visionary work of art will shake you to the bone, break your heart, and electrify your conscience as it engulfs you in the wonders and horrors of the New World.


Story: 10/10


Shinsekai Yori takes place on Earth far into the future, in a post-apocalyptic world after mankind develops the ability to use PK, or psychokinesis, the ability to manipulate kinetic energy and reconstruct matter. The vehicle for the story is a group of five friends from the town of Kamisu 66, who find themselves in the same Class Group on their first day of school, after manifestation of their powers upon reaching puberty. The viewers are given insight into the day to day lives of these children, such as attending school, eating dinner, and going on camping trips. The starting point allows us to grow with them and experience what they experience as a child would, gradually unravelling the mysteries of the world around them. Mystery, of course, is the name of the game. For this New World is not quite like the one we know. For despite their grandiose powers and way of life, the humans live under a shroud of fear for both the dangers that haunt the night, and the darkness that steadily creeps within their own society. 


From there, we watch the children grow up, as they develop relationships, make discoveries, and find themselves in a perpetual midst of peril, sometimes as a product of their own trouble-making, and other times as a product of their fated circumstances. The beauty of this story is that all of these components are seemlessly and simultaneously integrated into the story, like a triple helix. There are so many parts moving all at once, but it's not overly complicated as to lose the viewers interest. As the story progresses, we dive deeper and deeper into the web of the world that the author weaves for us, picking up bread crumbs along the way, all while the characters endear themselves to us along a journey of discovery. It's all very realistic, and beautifully done. The story is not just about discovery and friendship of course. For there is a looming danger beyond the horizon. This of course, is the main plot of the story, and it takes a culmination of the entire series to realize and resolve. Without giving too much away, it's completely unpredictable yet brilliantly obvious and will hit you like a train. 


As I mentioned earlier, this story begins with our heroes after reaching puberty at age 12, but the plot actually time-jumps later on to their lives at ages 14 and 26, eventually concluding with our main character as she turns 36. Each of these main time frames (age 12, 14, and 26) corresponds with one of the three mythical creatures that's introduced to us early in the story, namely the Trickster Cat, the Karmic Demon, and the Ogre. These three myths act as a sort of theme and bookmark for each of the main chapters of the story, which can be further broken down into 5 separate arcs, if you include the False Minishiro and the Monster Rats. Confused? Good, you don't need to know any of that to truly appreciate this piece, for unlike similar stories in this genre, all of the mysteries of the future will be explained in due time in the most satisfying of ways. In other words, you don't need me to explain everything to you. Just be prepared to have your mind blown.


What doesn't get fully explained, however, is what became of some of some of the characters (Shun, Maria and Mamoru), relationships (Satoru and Shun, Satoru and Saki), and plot elements (Saki's ability to reconstruct telomeres). A lot of that is sort of left unresolved or half-baked, perhaps out of necessity for time. The society's resolution and any potential move for change toward the end wasn't really explained either. But this does little to take away from the main point of the story. What does take away from the story however, is one particular episode (episode 22) that wasn't really up to par with the rest of the series. It was just sort of out of place in terms of quality because of some minor uses of deux ex machina (which was completely non-existent up to this point), lack of research (such as mistating how some well-known chemical compounds work), and just lackluster storytelling in general (in that it was kind of boring despite it's premise for action). It caused me to momentarily snap out of the world they had immersed me in for 21 episodes and back to reality. This one episode even caused me to question whether the producers had the talent to bring the story full circle (they did). But in essence, episode 22 is a great illustration of Shinsekai Yori's greatest challenge - it's own extremely ambitious expectations. But it's a good testament as to the strength of the series as a whole to say that out of this entire 25 episode series, there was only one episode that I found to be imperfect. 


Art: 10/10


A-1 Pictures did the animation for this series. You might remember them from animes such as Ao Exorcist, SAO, and most recently Aldnoah Zero. However, the art in Shinsekai Yori seems more akin to that of Princess Mononoke, except enhanced to a modern HD quality. The action and animation does remind me a bit of Ao Exorcist, however. In case you're unfamiliar, both references were major compliments. The scenery of the world is beautifully drawn. The characters, even moreso. The designs of the other creatures that inhabit the world were terrifying, but in a good way. The only thing I found a little strange about the artwork was that I felt that when the characters grew older, their necks got a little too long. But that's something that's hardly noticeable, without someone pointing it out to you. Oops. Regardless, the art is of a very high quality, and the design is spectacularly creative. The directoral contributions also deserves a shoutout. What more is there to say.


Sound: 10/10


Let's start by noting there's no opening song to this anime. That's mainly because the creators were focused on immersion into the world they created, and having an intro song would have come off a bit tacky for a work of art like this. It did have a closing song though, three actually, and they worked well. The first closing, Wareta Ringo by Risa Taneda was easily the best. It was very catchy, fit well with the story, and was maybe even Ipod worthy. The other two aren't very noteworthy since they weren't on the show very long, nor were they very memorable. The sound effects, and background music was all very well put-together, and was crucial to creating the air of tension and suspense upon which the story was set. The voice acting was also very good, although I've only seen the dub for this anime. I noticed that the male lead character for the english dub sounded a lot like the guy who played Sunohara in Clannad, which I thought was hilarious for some reason. The characters actually aren't very similar. I think they did a good job of changing the voice acting slightly as the characters aged while retaining their unique speaking styles, particularly with the deepening of tones. Although, they might have gone a little overboard with the female lead character's narrator voice (supposedly at age 36), which was way lower than the cutesy voice she spoke with for the vast majority of the story (between ages 12-26). It's not really that big of a deal though. In short, it might be worthwhile to note that this is one of those animes where you can literally identify each and every character by their voice alone. Pretty impressive if you asked me. 


Characters: 10/10


The thing that struck me as special about this anime was that none of the characters were driven by plot devices - the fate that typically moves stories along. In other words, characters didn't do things inexplicably merely to move the plot along. Rather, each character stayed true to who they were, and made realistic decisions based on their past experiences. They asked the same questions we would have asked, were we in their shoes, and made the same decisions we would have made. This all added to the sense of realism to the whole experience.


Shinsekai Yori really pulled away from the pack in terms of character development. While at the start of the series, there's a slight hint of cliche anime archetypes - the loud obnoxious wild child, the cute and quiet tsundere girl, the beautiful and outgoing best friend, the handsome genius, the random guy that doesn't talk. But as the story progresses, these archetypes are quickly dispelled as we discover something deeper within them at the core of who they are. They're all clever, lovable, and beautiful children. But they're also all unique individuals, causing us to miss each of them when they're gone. For example, with the main character, Saki, I couldn't help but find there was something about her that drew me as a viewer to her. The story strangely mischaracterizes this trait as "strength." But by the time I reach the final scenes, I realized that what made her special wasn't strength or tenacity, but rather her endless capacity to love even the greatest of her enemies.  Even the antagonists were sympathetic, as they were acting in accordance with their own circumstances for survival. The lines of good and evil were blurred in a sense. There weren't any "bad guys" per se. It's much more complex than that. 


Speaking of complexity, I'm sure most of you have heard of the term Love Triangle. Well, the relationship web in this anime is more like a Gyroelongated Triangular Bipyramid than any Triangle I've ever seen. Basically Girl A falls in love with Boy B, who's dating Boy A, who's in love with Boy B, who's actually in love with Girl A, who's dating Girl B, who's in love with Girl A, who sleeps with Boy A, who if you remember, was her love rival for the affections of Boy B. Girl A also sleeps with Girl B, and Boy A also sleeps with Boy B. Girl B also sleeps with Boy C, who's in love with her, even though she's in love with Girl A. 


Strange as it may sound, it all actually makes a lot of sense when you see it all play out, and the ones you hope will end up together strangely do so. Despite all this love tangling, there really isn't a whole lot of jealous infighting going around because the five friends all support and love each other very much, and for good reason. Plus, they have bigger things to worry about. It's all rather genuine. None of the relationships seem forced, which only makes each goodbye that much more heart-breaking. The dialogue is also fantastic, with one particular monologue in episode 16 being the best monologue I've ever heard from an anime.


One thing you may have noticed is that pretty much all of the characters are bisexual. One important thing to keep in mind though is that their world and social norms are completely different from our own, so it would be silly to judge them by our standards today. In particular, sex in their society serves a function beyond mere reproduction that's explained briefly early on and will make more sense if you've been paying attention up to the final arc. As such, sexual conduct is encouraged, regardless of gender or even age really. It's an interesting look at a society indifferent to modern groupthink notions of love and sex. There's no porn though, so don't worry, and you don't have to be bisexual to enjoy the show, obviously. But it's probably not for children under 13. 


Enjoyment: 9/10


Visionary, Immersive, Thought-provoking are the words that best describe this work of art. And at its core, it is simply that - a work of art. For this reason, the only category where this piece fails to receive a Perfect 10 is in the Enjoyment department. While I would easily rate this series above well-regarded heavyweight contenders such as Code Geass and Steins Gate, I didn't really enjoy this anime as much as I enjoyed the aforementioned shows.  That's not to say Shinsekai Yori is not enjoyable. The art and action were fantastic, the characters are likeable, and the story is one of the most thrilling and memorable I've seen in a long time. What I mean is that the show, in general, doesn't really seem all that concerned with entertaining you for the duration of its 25 episodes. There's no fan service or clever quips, there's very little humor, and the episodes only end with a cliffhanger every once in a while. This piece was more focused on story-telling and realism, like a true work of art.


Another thing that hurts its score as far as enjoyment goes is that it is extremely thought-provoking, which sounds like a good thing, right? Well, not for the average viewer who's looking to relax on his coach and kill some brain cells. This show will force you to take a good long hard look at who we are as a society, where we come from, and where we are headed, even going as far as to call into question what it means to be human. For that reason, it is not a lazy watch by any means. Those are some things to keep in mind when deciding whether and when to give this anime a shot. In my opinion, this is one that's best left for a rainy day when you've seen it all, but just want to have your mind blown one last time.


Overall: 10/10


All in all, Shinsekai Yori is one of the most memorable series you'll ever watch, and rewatch. It is a staple of hidden gem animes. Give it a chance, and if you have questions or want to discuss, feel free to message me. Until next time, Cheers!

“Shinsekai Yori” which translates to “From the New World.”
There is something ominous about this anime. One can’t help but wonder, if what was shown there might actually become a reality in the distant future. It has a powerful vibe and I can’t help but feel Wells, Orwell and Huxley having a combined influence on the story structure; as far as utopia with mind-control, behavior control, and superiority among humans with huge potential differences are considered.
You just sit there and let the anime sweep you alongside it, everything in the anime are perfectly blended, and at one point you’d feel whether the mangaka is actually fromthe future, writing out a story according to his experiences. Not only is the story deep, thought-provoking and frightening, it also shows a much darker side of humanity; what are the consequences of absolute law? What are consequences of secrecy in a society at large? How much of truth is there in the old saying “curiosity killed the cat?” How far are we willing to go to protect humanity? Why are we the only beings with sentient minds?


So, what makes this anime such a grand piece, or put more aptly, an unappreciated gem.


Animation – 9/10


The animation is done by A-1 Pictures, and well, they outdid themselves again. There is always a forbearing dread that something is lurking in the corner, the animation is brilliant, it shows the darkness with color, yet the scenery with vivid energy, the villages with tranquil, and the new creatures evolved in a thousand years so realistically, one would actually be inclined to believe that they might someday come around. The color achieves so much.


Characters – 9/10


Hail redheads!

One of the things that I loved about this anime was the characters. The characters were just…..beautiful. For such an ominous story to flow one needs characters, and the characters here do justice to the story. They are shown in three points of their lives; childhood, teenage and adulthood. One might remain skeptical about whether character development through three stages of growth is possible in a 25-episode anime, but trust me, Shinsekai Yori pulls it off magnificently, this can be seen clearly with characters like Saki and Satoru, with Saki being the narrator, and the main character of the series. You feel at one with them; there was a time when I was actually saying to myself; “Please let these two survive.” And not only the main characters, even despicable characters like Squealer show magnificent character development. But then again, who am I to call Squealer despicable?

Did I mention I’m completely biased towards Maria?


Music – 9/10


Oh. My. God.

The music can be called something that is truly “beautiful.” You can’t help but fall in love with the haunting melody, chilling composition and how effortlessly, the music complements the story. It’s like two very dark components kiss.


Story – 9/10


A millennium from now, in Japan, exists a utopia. The protagonist, Saki Watanabe, lives in an idyllic village barred from the outside world. Her world is ruled by the people who possess the "gods' power" of psychokinesis. After finally obtaining her own powers, Saki enters the Zenjin Academy to train along with five other children: Satoru Asahina, Maria Akizuki, Mamoru Itou, Shun Aonuma, and Reiko Amano.

Not all is as it seems, however. In this utopian village, strange rumors about a monstrous cat that abducts children circulate, and students are said to disappear from the academy. The world and its history are much darker than they appear and humanity is on the verge of collapse.

Well, that’s how the synopsis is described, and telling anything further would be spoilers.


Entertainment – 9.5/10


I binge-watched, in a hospital room, overnight, while munching on spice-less hospital food; that is how much I enjoyed this show. This is not for a casual watch, or for people who’re easily bored or looking for cheap laughs or easy sexual gratification. If you’re looking for a paced thought-provoking story, driving characters and won’t compromise on sound and visuals, this one is for you.


In short, Shinsekai Yori is a beautiful yet underappreciated gem in the current anime scene, where people are more focused on anime with food for the body rather than food for the mind.


Overall score – 9.1

Initially I thought this was going to suck.  I'm almost positive that I audibly groaned the first time I watched an episode thinking to myself "wow, this looks insanely childish."  The art grew on me.  Just about everything with this anime grew on me and I'm pretty sure that's why I like it so much today.  I know there are people out there who watched this show when it premiered in 2012, but I feel like a lot of us overlooked it entirely and that's kind of a shame.
The story creeps.  It sticks with you.  It could just beme I am pretty malleable, but something about this show really irked and inspired me.  It's a sad reminder that most of us humans are reptilian in laymens terms and that we don't ever really learn, but somehow persist.


Even when we probably shouldn't.

Please read this before you attempt to watch this anime. You may take this warning with a grain of salt as I have only watched 8 episodes but after being thoroughly pertubed, I have done a lot of secondary research and this is the conclusion I have reached. This anime is not worth your time and here is why if you want an explanation/evidence.  
   From what I have gathered, the way this anime works is, excluding the first episode, the anime is entirely shitty filler until the final arc which I have heard people say is absolutelyamazing and deep and others say is clichéd and easily found in other anime. Idk, I didn’t watch the end. But even the people that highly rate this anime generally agree that this anime is not enjoyable. Deep, dark, and thought provoking yes but not an enjoyable watch. Some people praise this difference in story telling and seem to be genuinely fine with the all moral no entertainment type of story. Others get off on thinking that being able to value something for reasons other than enjoyment makes them more mature than others and will dismiss all criticisms of the piece as being made by “immature simpletons” whose brains are too underdeveloped to appreciate something this deep. But me personally I watch anime for enjoyment, and while a deeper meaning to anime is a very welcome and cherished experience, I am not willing to torture or bore myself to death myself just to obtain this.



    The reason I didnt watch the end is because the middle is so bad. There are various random plot elements scattered throughout the middle which means you have to sit through it to get to the end. So lets get into why the middle is bad.


  There are various reviews labeled 3-4 (and even some 10s) on the MAL page that will perform a much better analysis of this shows specific shortcomings so I will simply list the basics without going into much detail or providing examples. Take them as you will but I can attest that I truly felt and recognized these issues while watching the anime and that I am not simply parroting the specific negatives others had identified while vaguely not liking the anime.


1. There are no interesting characters and there is no character developement. 

2. The world and is magic system while somewhat interesting, are very shoddily built and frustratingly vague or self contradictory

3. There is no “good” comedy, action, or romance to temporarily sate you while you wait for the story to get istelf in gear at the very end

4. The 3 aforementioned factors combined lead to a very unnatural and uncomfortable watch as everything you know about good storytelling is ripped to shreds. You could pretty objectively say that the author did not write a good story. How much of this is on purpose snd how much of this is simply a lack of talent or foresight who knows and does it matter if its unenjoyable all the same.


There are definitely many more major issues I could talk about, any many more comparisons I could make to try and explain it to you, but for brevitiy’s sake just know that the middle section definitely does not feel good. And for me it feels really bad.


So these factors combined make it so you sit through the most horrible mundane shit slowly gathering the few important plot points while you wait for something to happen. Considering this anime is 24 episodes long and the reviews of the ending have ranged from amazing all the way down  to meh, you really have to ask yourself if this is a gamble worth taking. I personally have made my choice and decided that it isnt worth the risk. To paraphase another reviewers words there are much better anime like Shiki and Eve no Jikan that deliver a similar and probably better highly philisophical/ thought provoking message without taking the time to drag you throught the mud and insult your intelligence first. So maybe if you have seen these other reccomendations and you have a lot of time and patience you can watch this but If not i would suggest watching them first and then still not watching this anime. Thats how much I personally disliked what I did watch.



Thank you for taking your time to read this review. I very much am open to comments and critiques on my review as I am always trying to expand my critical mind, and this review was quite fundsmentally different from my other reviews. Also if you want to try and convince me that the ending message of shinsekai yori is sooo good and lifechanging  that it is worth me slogging through the rest even after watching the aforementioned suggestions first.

I don't even care if I get slayed for this, I'm just going to say it, this anime is a big mess and just extremely sloppy...
I've read reviews where people were saying how the anime was deep and took a lot of analysis or that it is realistic.... Personally, I think the writers for the anime was trying very hard to be deep and artistic... They honestly should have just followed the manga a bit more closely.
The story was simply poorly executed, intriguing at first but then the characters themselves just kind of throw that out of the dust with their irrational thinking, and no,just because they are children and they are from a closed off utopia does not automatically excuse them of their stupidity.\n
We start off with a sort of mystery about the world outside and the world in their little village and our main characters are given the "truth" from this weird... jelly.... thing... that was really unnecessary design in my point of view. The children are shocked about what they hear and before they can find out more they are discovered and immediately in trouble... If they were to go back to the village and just have their eyes opened to have fucked up their village is and they fight to survive or change it, that would have been a lot better!!! But no, instead we are put on a spot where they forcibly put the characters in an awkward and random almost sex scene which was just... what the flying fuck? Then a war between the queerats which literally came from nowhere. Since when could queerats actually SPEAK human language, I knew they had their own language but apparently they can speak like humans too? Fine, fine, I will accept that... we move on...\n
Satoru gets his abilities back and instead of getting back to the village for safety... he claims they have to fight them so that they aren't in danger anymore. Uhm, why not just hurry back to the village and ohh... I don't know.. GET HELP? Apparently killing and stuff is only bad when you do it to humans but the writers and director DOES realize that killing and cruelty to animals is one of the signs of becoming a killer or serial killer, right? And these weren't just animals, they had human intelligence. But oh well~ I guess that doesn't matter, despite the fact that they are in the future and that study is and was an easily known fact!! Pfft, not at all, no big deal if you destroy and entire colony of the species. As you can tell, this is when I really started to dislike the anime.\n\n
